"DUTCH WEEK." "MEATS OF THE WORLD SALUTES DUTCH MEAT."

dialogues.speaker: VARIOUS SHOTS OF SAN FRANCISCO
dialogues.text: Over this we hear a recording of Jack Kerouac's poem, San Francisco which is accompanied by a BE-BOP trio. Kerouac' poetry coincides with the various shots of San Francisco. come to a sign for Jack Kerouac Street. We PAN OVER to "T CITY LIGHTS BOOKSTORE" and continue along to the ALLEYWAY where there is a large high-contrast black and white sign depicting Jack Kerouac in his famous "I'm looking into th distance, having a brilliant thought" pose... CHARLIE MACKENZIE, in his late twenties, wearing a flanne shirt and torn jeans, walks INTO THE FRAME, right in fron of the picture of Jack Kerouac and inadvertently strikes exact same pose. We PULL BACK to reveal that Charlie has bag of garbage in his right hand, which he deposits in th alleyway. We FOLLOW Charlie into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We FOLLOW him through the store. By day he is the Assista Manager, by night he is a poet. A MAN in his fifties, wearing a beret and a goatee is rea Charles Bukowski's, Playing The Piano Like a Percussive  Instrument, Until Your Fingers Begin To Bleed A Bit. Charlie takes his place behind the cash register and resu writing in his handsome leather-bound poetry journal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUSTOMER approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have the book On The Road by  Jack Kerouac?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every day there is a steady stream of tourists who come i to get copies of On The Road. Charlie is use to this and  without looking up he points to a huge, well marked displ of thousands of copies of On The Road. Another TOURIST CO approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a copy of On The Road by  Jack Kerouac?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again not looking up, Charlie just points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie puts the "CLOSED" sign on the door and proceeds t walk home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sights and the sounds of the city are accentuated by BEBOP as he sees life, warts and all. As the streets beco less populated, he can now hear the sounds of his own  FOOTSTEPS and, a COUPLE BICKERING. The streets become eve more deserted. The night is closing in on him. A cat dart out from an alleyway and startles him. He quickens his pa RUMBLINGS make him cross the street to avoid the danger.  Headlights of a slow moving car approach from the distanc Charlie, frightened, turns another corner onto:

dialogues.speaker: HIS STREET
dialogues.text: He approaches a 3-story Victorian home, in which he has a apartment on the second floor, he notices a light on in h window. A CRASHING sound from within.

dialogues.speaker: HANDS
dialogues.text: taking papers out of a desk drawer.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: carefully opening the front door and then gingerly closin it. He reaches for a baseball bat in a nearby umbrella st Sound of BREAKING GLASS from his apartment upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: SHATTERED PICTURE FRAME
dialogues.text: with a photo of Charlie and an angelic blonde.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: finishing off the last two steps nearing the front door o his apartment, bat raised above his head ready to swing.

dialogues.speaker: THE HANDS
dialogues.text: clasp a jewelry box on the top of the dresser and stuff t into a dufflebag; the jewelry is followed by CD's.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: pushing open his apartment door in a mock SWAT maneuver,  then stealthily stalking toward the sound of the intruder the bedroom. He stubs his toe on a spring loaded doorstop making a loud metal VITTSWINGGGG's sound. He freezes,  terrified.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEDROOM
dialogues.text: where the HANDS, freeze.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Like a coiled jungle cat ready to pounce, waits two beats then springs Samurai style into...

dialogues.speaker: THE BEDROOM
dialogues.text: He freezes.

dialogues.speaker: REVEAL
dialogues.text: that the HANDS belong to the angelic blonde in the broken picture. It's Charlie's girlfriend, SHERRI.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sherri! What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm leaving you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thank God... I thought you were  robbing our own home, because frankly,  that's insane. I mean, what could  you possibly gain by robbing your  own home? I don't mean to meddle,  but isn't it better to rob other  peoples' homes? Start accumulating  their wealth as opposed to just  reaccumulating your own wealth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not funny, Charlie. I'm really  leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She continues to pack. Charlie tries to unpack her things

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?! Just because we had a fight  last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've had a fight every night for  two months. Ever since I brought up  the subject of marriage, you've found  fault with everything I do. Why  couldn't we have gotten married,  Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) I'm too young to get married. (begins putting her  things back) I'm only twenty-nine and a half. We  love living together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been two years now. I need  something more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, Sherri, this is frustrating for  me, okay. When we first started going  out I thought we agreed that we  weren't the sort of people who got  married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's like saying we're not the  sort of people who are going to grow  old. We're not going to fall into  that "growing old" trap. Face it,  you've got a problem with commitment,  Charlie. Take a look at your other  girlfriends. Every time you get close  to a commitment there's something  wrong with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I broke up with them for good  reasons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Sandy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sandy was an alcoholic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No-no-no. You thought she was an  alcoholic. She just drank more than  you drank. What about Jill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hated my family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You thought she hated your family.  Nobody hates your family. Everybody  loves your family. What about Julie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smelled like soup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smelled exactly like Campbell's  Beef Vegetable soup. She was dirty,  physically dirty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Charlie, I wonder what you're  gonna say were my problems? Are you  gonna tell your friends that I was a  junkie, that I wasn't supportive  enough or that I smelled like relish?  Charlie, I loved you. It could have  worked out. (she goes to the door) Think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie and his best friend, TONY SPILETTI, are out for a night on the town. Tony is second generation Italian-American with very  Mediterranean features. They're listening to Teenage Fan  Club. They pass Ghierardeli Square.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony, Teenage Fan Club, they're  Scottish you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had that dream again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, is that the one where you suspect  that a fat man in a diaper, on a  lazy susan has interfered with your  plans for the evening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but I have had that one. No, in  this one I'm in love...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I say to myself, 'I've finally  found somebody that I'm truly  comfortable with.' You know when  you're so comfortable that you'll  let them put makeup on you to see  what you would look like if you were  a girl. Anyways you know what I do  in the dream next?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You propose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause) No. I die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Charlie, you're a normal suburban  guy at heart, from a normal suburban  family. Didn't you tell me you always  wanted to get married and have a  family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but, I'm afraid, okay? There  are seven main rites of passage in a  man's life. Birth, first day of  school, last day of school. Marriage.  Kids. Retirement. Death. I'm at  marriage. I'm two rites of passage  away from death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I wasn't listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony is doing three-sixties, scoping out beauties, when  suddenly his roving eyes lock on a police car directly be them. He slouches down into his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ. It's the cops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony, you are a cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Isn't it awful? I work with  those guys. They're assholes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police car passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony and Charlie enter. There is a poet on stage. The clu is full of art tarts and college bohemians. They are gree by the club's owner, GIUSEPPI, an Italian man in his fift

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salve zio mio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allora? Che catzo fai, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Uncle Giuseppi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony, come' stai bello il tuo pappa  e' in galera per la terza volta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony's uncle shows them to a table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have the waitress bring you  cappuccino.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did your uncle say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says my Dad's back in jail again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, I'm sorry, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, it's funny I don't even  feel related to my parents anymore.  I feel like your mom and dad are  more like my parents. I feel more  Scottish than Italian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony Spiletti, I don't think you  could get more Italian than that.  Unless of course your name was Tony  Italian Guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie checks out the girls in the coffee bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so bummed. Sherri was great,  wasn't she? I'm an asshole, aren't  I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got to help me get through  this night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've just got to get back on the  horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waitress arrives with two cappuccinos in extremely la cups like they have in France.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waitress, I'm sorry, there seems to  be a mistake. I ordered the large  cappuccino.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two girls at a nearby table, laugh. Charlie and Tony exch "This could be promising." looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the girls) Do you think these cups could be  larger? They're practically bowls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls laugh again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel like I'm having Campbell's  Cuppuccino.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Join us in a cup of coffee? There's  enough room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls come over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name's Susan and this is June. We  think you're funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name's Tony. This is my friend  Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Tony, I'm going home. See you  later, girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony grabs him and pulls him aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really don't understand, do you?  When a girl comes over to your table  and says, 'I think you're funny.' It  means you've pretty much been given  the keys to the city. Charlie, this  is big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you've confused me with  someone who gives a shit. Here's  what's gonna happen, Tony. We'll end  up going out with them tonight, maybe  even home with them. Well go out for  two months. Soon she'll move in,  we'll be happy, She'll want more of  a commitment. I'll be terrified and  I'll do something to ruin it. Just  like I did with Sherri.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves. Tony is left with the two girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor, guy... He seemed so nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (talking, choked up) I just broke up with somebody as  well. She left me high and dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girls try to comfort him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three quarters of the furnishings and items have disappea with Sherri. Charlie sits dejectedly on the floor over hi Poetry Journal. He is missing Sherri. We see...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE'S FACE
dialogues.text: He looks out and is struck by an idea and begins to write

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE'S FACE
dialogues.text: Again he looks out, finds his inspiration and continues t write

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE'S FACE
dialogues.text: A gentle tear rolls down his left cheek. He pauses, then  finishes off the stanza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After the last line he scratches out the entire poem. He  closes the book and turns on the TV set to CNN to veg out The show is "What's Cooking! With Burt Wolf."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie is driving in his car. He drives slowly looking f an address. Finds it, slips in to a parking spot in front

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adorning the front are a "GRAND OPENING" sign and miniatu flags of the world. Charlie goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a small, hip shop selling specialty meats from aroun the world. Charlie looks around. Suddenly, an attractive  woman in her late twenties, wearing a blood-stained smock enters. It is HARRIET MICHAELS. She has a cleaver in one  hand and something bloody in the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry) Goddamn shoplifter. (conscious of Charlie's  presence; holding up  bloody meat) But I got him! (smiles) You're next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (backing out the door;  terrified) I've come at a bad time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No stay!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, really... Obviously you've  got things you have to do. You've  got to dismember the rest of his  bloody torso. Dig a makeshift shallow  grave. Cover the body with quick  lime. Really so much to do, so little  time and I'm only in the way here,  I'm just gonna go. Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (referring to meat in  hand) Oh, this! Oh, no, this is what he  stole. This isn't a piece of him or  anything. This is Icelandic Shank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet it goes well with a nice  Chianti. Fittfittfitt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Do you have haggis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, we do. It's over here in our  Scottish Cuts section. One?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a section under glass flying a Scottish flag, wit haggis and various cuts of Scottish meat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! I've never been able to find  haggis anywhere, except at my parents'  house. They're Scottish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet rounds the counter and wraps up the haggis. Behin her is the large "PRUSSIAN VENISON" sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ringing up his order) That'll be fifteen, seventy-nine.  Will there be anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I know it's a long shot, but  you wouldn't by any chance happen to  have any Prussian Venison?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now where in the world would I get  Prussian Venison?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie's charmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie is driving along listening to Kerouac. We absorb flavor of San Francisco as he drives down Lombard Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old crappie apartment building in San Francisco. Charl car pulls up. We hear "SATURDAY NIGHT" by the Bay City  Rollers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie approaches a door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling up) Mom, Dad, I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in here, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The apartment is a shrine to Scotland. Scottish paraphern miniature Scotty dogs, shortbread tins and, on wall, fram pictures depict famous Scotsmen, Sean Connery, Jackie Ste Alexander Graham Bell, James Doohan (Scottie from "Star  Trek"), Sheena Easton, Billy Connolly.

dialogues.speaker: AS WE ENTER THE LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: We see STUART, MAY, TONY, and little WILLIAM, Charlie's  fourteen year old little brother all singing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) S-A-T-U-R-D-A-Y... NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (noticing Charlie) Come give your old man a kiss or  I'll kick your teeth in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group are eating dinner on TV trays. Charlie walks ov and turns off the record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie, put on Charlie Pride, would  ya? Oh, I love Charlie Pride. (begins singing; in  thick Scottish accent) HEY, DID YOU HAPPEN TO SEE THE MOST  BEAUTIFUL GIRL IN THE WORLD...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May, shut it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STUART MACKENZIE is in his late fifties, a butcher, with  Coke bottle glasses and thick head of black hair. His red haired wife, MAY, is in her fifties, attractive with a so but tough appearance. Little WILLIAM, has a very large he and a skinny neck. Like Charlie, he was born in America. Charlie gives his Mom a hug, his father a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, William.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on his stomach on  the floor; watching

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCORES! MAGIC GOAL!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the television, Stuart's team, Glasgow Celtic, has sco

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye -- magic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's have a look at the re-play.  William, move your head. Look at the  size of that ooy's heed. I'm not  kidding. It's like an orange on a  tooth pick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuart, you're going to give the boy  a complex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not kidding. That's a huge  noggin'. It has it's own weather  system. It's a virtual planetoid. (shouting to William) Heed! Move!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the re-play of the goal on TV. Tony sits down and brings over a plate of stew and three types of potatoes,  piled very high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that enough potatoes, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough to recreate Devil's Tower in  "Close Encounters".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sniffs the air) Do I smell haggis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye, you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking it) I'll put it in the frig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie notices Tony reading some papers. He realizes it' literature from the Lyndon H. LaRouche Society.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, what are you doing to Tony now?  Why do you abuse his mind like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the latest report from Lyndon  H. LaRouche, outlining how the Queen  and the Rothschilds masterminded the  Soviet overthrow, so that they could  reclaim lands they had annexed during  the Holy Roman Empire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (goading Charlie) You know a lot of this makes sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're suffering from the  Stockholm Syndrome, where the hostages  start to relate to their captors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Sonny Jim, it's a known fact  there's a society of the five  wealthiest people in the world, called  the Pentaverate, who run everything  and meet three times a year at a  secret country mansion in Colorado,  known as "The Meadows."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) And that's obviously why we haven't  heard about it in the newspapers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (inappropriately angry  & loud) That's right. They fuckin' own the  papers, smartass. And everything  else. Why do you think Scotland's  not been able to get independence?  Because the Queen the Pentavirate  and those English dome heads in West  Minster won't have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are the other members of this  pentaverate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen, the Rothchilds, the Gettys,  the Vatican, and Colonel Sanders  before he went tits up. Oh, I hated  the Colonel with his wee beady eyes.  And that smug look on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad how can you hate "the Colonel?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because the Colonel puts an addictive  chemical in it that makes you crave  it fortnightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interesting... coo-coo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would anyone like a juice? Charlie,  did I tell you, we bought a Juice  Tiger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Juice Tiger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye, it's a juicer. It's part of my  National Enquirer, Garth Brooks diet.  Would you like potato juice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sherri's late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, uh, Sherri and I broke up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you didn't. Sherri was the  daughter your father was never able  to give me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just not ready for marriage. I'm  twenty-nine and my poems haven't  even been published yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's not just the poetry is it  son? You're afraid if you get married  you'll lose your muse. Look at me, I  was a strapping young butcher, at  the height of my creative powers.  When it came to de-boning a side of  beef, there was nobody that could  touch me. Then I married your mother.  And people would still stand in awe  as I filleted a shoulder of lamb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it's just as well not to get  married, look at the news. Where did  I put it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heed. Move that melon of yours into  the bathroom and get the paper for  your mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William gets the National Enquirer and brings it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not news, Dad. That's bullshit.  I wouldn't wipe my ass with that  paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? It's the  fifth highest circulating paper in  the United States, I'll have you  know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, here it is. Mrs. X. The Honeymoon  Murderer. She marries men under fake  identities, and then murders them.  She killed some German martial arts  expert, and some plumber named Ralph  Elliot. Her whereabouts are unknown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's another goal on the TV set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scores! Two nil. Magic!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, beautiful goal. We HOLD on the  TV set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time passes. The TV set

dialogues.speaker: TO THE END OF THE GAME
dialogues.text: The two teams are shaking hands. And the final scores chy shows Celtic beating Rangers three nothing. We see Charli and Tony are leaving. Stuart is blind drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing Rod Stewart's  song) YOU'RE IN MY EYES, YOU'RE IN MY  DREAMS... YOU'RE CELTIC, UNITED  AND BABY I'VE DECIDED...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, you're steaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She meets Charlie and Tony at the door and kisses him goo bye. She turns to kiss Tony, and holds on the kiss far to long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling away) See you later, Mrs. MacKenzie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you've turned into a sexy Italian  bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you later, mom. (calling out) See you later, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Go! You've stayed your hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie and Tony leave and enter...

dialogues.speaker: THE HALLWAY
dialogues.text: where they find William sitting on the stairs waiting for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take me with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie's drives by and notices Harriet, who's unwinding store awning in Dutch national costume. The banner announ

dialogues.speaker: "DUTCH WEEK." "MEATS OF THE WORLD SALUTES DUTCH MEAT."
dialogues.text: Charlie slows down to look at her. She looks great in her little Dutch costume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie is again writing at the counter. Another PERSON  enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. You wouldn't happen to  have...

dialogues.text: (she laughs) That was easy -- What a nice guy.  You've probably never done a mean  thing in your life.

dialogues.text: "Brutal" is such a subjective word.  I mean, what's brutal to one person  might be totally reasonable to  another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinks) Well, I know everyone always say  "sense of humor", but I'd have to go  with breast size. (she laughs) How about you? In a guy.

dialogues.text: Me likey how you thinkey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On his way out, he peeks into the bedroom, where he finds bed that is facing neither parallel nor perpendicular wit the wall. It is just kind of "there".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming into room) I only have chamomile. I hope that's  all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at her and then at the "Oddly-placed" bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's North-South. (to his confused look) For health reasons. See... I had  this friend, he was a martial arts  expert. Anyways, he used to sleep  North-South. I don't know... It's a  martial arts thing and it just sort  of became a habit with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking into living  room) You know Scotland has it's own martial  arts. It's called FUCKU. It's mostly  head butting and kicking people when  they're on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet starts laughing. Then so does Charlie. They lean  into each other. Pretty close. Too close even, and when i seems like they're going to kiss, Charlie suddenly gets  uncomfortable and looks at his watch.

dialogues.text: Late?

dialogues.text: No. No. Not for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who for then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who for then what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you looked at your watch and  said it wasn't late for you... I  wondered who it was late for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not me. No, Sir. Not here. (after a pause;  checking watch) Maybe it is late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, the truth is, yes, I had a  great time, and I'd like to kiss  you, but if we do kiss, then we'll  kiss on the couch and if we kiss on  the couch, then we'll kiss in the  bedroom, and once you're in the  bedroom -- Well, the thing is, I  always rush it. And this time I feel  like maybe I should wait. Maybe we  should let it build naturally and  grow, instead of just immediately  spending the night together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to spend the night together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sold) I have no problem with that.

dialogues.speaker: THE BEDROOM
dialogues.text: They are both fast asleep. She is curled up in his arms.  Suddenly, she begins to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie's eyes open. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes Ralph. I will. Ralph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie's smile fades. He sits up and looks at her. She i lying completely still on the bed, her eyes closed, and s sleep-talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now now Ralph!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (waking her) Harriet...? Harriet...? (as her eyes open) You were having a dream, or...? You  kept saying the name Ralph.

dialogues.text: Ralph?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ralph. I heard you say it.

dialogues.text: (sleepily) That's odd. Just today I was thinking  about, her. She's a friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting to leave) Is she nice --? Ralph...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. She's great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie is sleeping alone in the bed, and the sound of RU WATER is heard off in the distance. His eyes slowly open, looks around, remembers where he is. He puts on his short and walks towards the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the steam we can just make out Harriet in the sho washing her hair. Charlie walks over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know... with this drought in  California total strangers are urged  to shower together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God. I'm sorry. Jesus. Excuse me.

dialogues.text: He backs out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and a hurriedly dressed Charlie emerges. B he gets to the door he once again encounters Rose. She's  completely dressed. Even her hair is dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. I'm really sorry. I must have  scared the... I'm Harriet's friend,  Charlie, and you must be... (hopefully) Ralph?

dialogues.text: He reaches for it, but she reads it aloud to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) 'Dear Charlie, I didn't want to wake  you, make yourself at home, thanks  for making me smile.' Harriet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a very nice note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll make you some breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, I'd love to but I'm running  late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, that stuff'll kill you while  Fruit Loops are light and probably  reasonably high in Fiber. I like  Apple Jacks too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got 'em.

dialogues.text: So this is your apartment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. She's been here the past three  months... ever since she came back  from Miami. I used to visit her  occasionally. She didn't speak of  me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head, no) She told me about a martial arts guy  and there was some discussion about  Ralph...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She spoke of them...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She spoke of the martial arts guy  and screamed about Ralph...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (affectionately) Well, you know Harriet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I really don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) But you did have sex with her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taken aback) Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yet you still don't know her. (contemplates this) See, that's the problem with sex.  It's not very revealing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My, look at the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause) You should be careful, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am... usually. I just... You should  know, this is very unusual that I  would do this so soon, in this day  and age particularly, but... We just  really hit it off. We did. And...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna go now. I won't tell Harriet  that anything happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... nothing did happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. Or she would be jealous.  And when she gets jealous, we both  know what she's capable of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we don't. You do, like I said, I  just met her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be okay, Charlie. Just be  careful.

dialogues.text: Good. Good. Look, Fred... (leaning in) You got a lot of girlfriends, right?  You know any girls named Ralph?

dialogues.text: Tony and Charlie are waiting in line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as they travel to the island.

dialogues.text: You know I've lived in this city all  my life and I've never been to  Alcatraz.

dialogues.speaker: ALCATRAZ
dialogues.text: We open on the LOUD BANGING of a CELL DOOR. We find our t group in the holding area. The PARK RANGER is a beefy man his late fifties and talks with emotionless, military  precision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, everyone I'm a park ranger  and I will be leading you on the  tour. All the park rangers here at  Alcatraz were at one time guards,  myself included. My name is John  Johnson, but everyone here calls me  Vicki. Will you please follow me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are led out. We see that Alcatraz is a sinister plac Cold and unforgiving. The Park Ranger leads them to the c of a cell block.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're glowing, Charlie. The man's  in love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sssh... Stop it. I'm trying to listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the main cell block area.  Home to such famous criminals as Al  Capone, Micky Cohen, Joseph "Dutch"  Critzer, and Robert Stroud, the famous  Bird Man of Alcatraz. Follow me,  please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Park Ranger leads them past the famous visiting rooms the mess hall, all the way to the solitary confinement ar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the cell for solitary  confinement, that over the years has  come to be known as Times Square.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony and Charlie are at the back of the tour group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So did you and Harriet?... you know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) Sssh I don't want to talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With that look, you don't have to  talk about it. The grin alone could  get you five to seven years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony, get your mind out of the gutter.  All you need to know is that she's a  sweet, kind and loving person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now this is something none of the  other tour guides will tell you. In  this particular cell block Machine  Gunn Kelly had, what we call in the  prison system, a "bitch." And one  day, in a jealous rage, Kelly took a  makeshift knife, or "shiv," and cut  out his "bitch's" eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, what can I tell you. I'm  smitten. I'm in deep smit. I dunno.  I just don't wanna talk about it,  because then I start analyzing and  that's not good for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. I think that's good. Just let  it happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. That's what's gonna be  different this time. Something strange  happens, let it go. It's not my  business... Like Ralph. She says  Ralph in her sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Ralph?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know who Ralph is. Moreover,  I don't want to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And as if blinding his "bitch" wasn't  enough retribution for Kelly, the  next day he and four other inmates  took turns pissing into the "bitch's"  ocular cavity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony and Charlie look at each other. They're a little que

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. (beat) Tony, I'm happy. Don't let me screw  this one up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are eating Bay burrites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you have a nice date last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose, I don't really --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He disturbed me while I was naked in  the shower this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he stayed over?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mind. Charlie and I laughed  about it over breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said you had great sex last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He did? (a beat) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seems really stuck on you. I hope  for you that it lasts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose he's a sweet, kind and loving  person. We like each other, but I  don't want to think any further.  It's taken me a long time to get  back to dating, and I want to take  things real steady this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you can trust me not to tell  him anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was quite happy not to talk about  the past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did a sketch of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose shows the sketch to Harriet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at the picture) That's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think I've caught him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The eyes are good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie really liked it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a good likeness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, I really hope it works out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose, I don't wanna screw this one  up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie enters the building, holding a handful of poetry  books. He passes a UNIFORMED DELIVERY GUY coming out. The guy nods and Charlie nods back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie gets three feet down the hallway. Stops in his tr and heads back to the front door. He opens it and yells t the delivery guy:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, uh... Ralph...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning around) I'm Gilbert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET'S DOOR
dialogues.text: She opens the door enough to see that she is wearing only blouse that goes below her hips. She looks fantastic. He  hands her the poetry books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (teasing him) Charlie, they're beautiful. I'll put  them right in water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He follows her inside and puts the books on the bureau. H goes over and kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just getting dressed. (picking up skirt off  couch) What do you think of this skirt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honestly? (pulls her close) I'd leave it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So then you think I could go to a  poetry concert like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She drops the skirt and stands there. She's fantastic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's forget the poetry concert.  It's already been nine hours since I  last made love to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling; walking  away) Come on we're meeting your best  friend. I wanna look good. The second  I go to the ladies room he's gonna  tell you what he really thinks of  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He follows her to the bedroom door, constantly trying to  kiss her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Charlie. We have to be there  in fifteen minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (following her into  bedroom) Fifteen minutes. Perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She closes the door on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through door) Maybe later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought of calling you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (startled) Aaaahhh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie turns on his heel. Rose has appeared out of nowhe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause) To warn you, Charlie. (after a pause) There are just some things you should  know, about Harriet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About Harriet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About her past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't wanna know. I mean, look  everyone has some skeletons in their  past. I only care about the future.  Not the past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the thing. I may have to tell  Harriet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell her what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That we're lovers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not lovers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, and it's a damn shame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet walks in the room, fully dressed, and fully dazzl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope I'm not interrupting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feeling weird) No, not at all. We were just talking  about... Rose and I met yesterday,  so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet hugs Rose and then stands right next to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, don't you think we look alike?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, we do not. Harriet was always  prettier than me. And a heck of a  lot more popular. She always had  boyfriends. The only thing I ever  got was good grades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slightly uncomfortable) Good grades are good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's just being kind. Show Charlie  one of your photographs, Rose. Rose  is a great artist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Harriet. I don't want to. They're  not good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're so modest. If I weren't here  to brag for you, I just don't know... (taking out a  posterboard from  cabinet) Show it to him, Rose. Do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns it over and there is a picture there. A collage unrelated images put together. And it is beautiful. But it's very abstract. Violent perhaps. Confused definit He likes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beautiful...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you call it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot artists don't like to title  their work. They feel it biases the  viewer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is titled. It's called "I dunno".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie looks at it again, then at Rose, then at Harriet. It's all a little bizarre, but in a funny way he feels fo Rose. A hidden talented overshadowed by her sister's beau

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should get going, Charlie. Thanks,  Rose... See you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose, great to see you. We should  all go out together some time. The  three of us. That would be great.  That would be... interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie and Harriet walk out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie and Harriet wait in line with bohemian types and  poetry lovers from the suburbs, and all walks of life.  Directly behind them are TWO OLD LADIES. The marquee read

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're going to love Alan  Ginsberg. He's great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I know all about him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Charlie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony is getting out of a cab accompanied by Susan, the gi from Spiletti's Coffee House. He approaches Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry we're late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony throws his arms wide open and hugs one of the Little Old Ladies on the other side of Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be Harriet. I've heard a  lot about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Tony; re: Harriet) This is Harriet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Sorry. Of course. (whispering to Harriet) I apologize. Charlie described you  as much older. And heavier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Oh, he did...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Tony. This is my best  friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this is Susan. Charlie, you  remember her from Uncle Giuseppi's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're funny...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then she GIGGLES. The girls start inside, Tony lags back  with Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers to Charlie) I give Susan one night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALLEN GINSBERG is on stage. He is brilliant. Tony, Charli and Harriet are all amused. Susan is bored stiff. Charlie looking at Tony. Tony glances over at Susan and gives Cha an "Oh, well." look. Then he looks at Harriet and nods in approval of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four of them walk along the wharf. Charlie is at one those arcade games where you throw bean bags at the puppe and try and knock them down. Charlie knocks two down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more and you get your pick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Harriet) You do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Charlie. I'm the worst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, you'll be great...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The arcade man turns around to watch. Harriet winds up an throws the bean bag directly into his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry... I told you Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, you're okay, you're just  having control problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both start laughing. He puts his arm around her. In b.g. the wounded arcade man is being led away by a co-wor They continued down the boardwalk stand in front of a Hou of Horrors. It looks somewhat run down and Harriet looks questioningl at Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know this is really, really cheesy,  but in a way this is one of the places  in San Francisco I'm most proud of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, let's go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony nods agreement. Susan looks bored. They go inside th

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE OF HORRORS
dialogues.text: it's as low rent as Charlie described. The "KEEPER OF THE THRESHOLD" so described in a poorly written sign, is an  overweight man in his late twenties, wearing jeans and a  denim jacket and a little bit of scary makeup. He looks l a roadie for the band, KISS. He stands at a podium, smoki and reading a paper. As Charlie, Tony, Harriet and Susan  pass the Threshold Keeper, he takes a casual drag of his  cigarette, lets out a little smoke and with zero commitme utters:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet and Charlie enter Bill's Wax Museum. The OWNER of the wax museum greets them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. I'm Bill, welcome to my wax  museum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk over to the exhibits. There are exhibits of Abr Lincoln, Michael Jackson and Dolly Parton. As they look m closely they notice that the faces are exactly the same a Bill's. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pouring rain. THUNDER. Charlie and Harriet, wrapped in ea others arms, walking through the rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel so safe with you right now.  You're never going to leave me, are  you? I feel like I could be here  forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PULL BACK to see Charlie in bed. He lies awake on his sid his back up to Harriet's. She is sound asleep. Suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sleeptalking) Ralph! No, Ralph!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie sighs, then just shrugs and tries to fall asleep. What can he do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie and Harriet wait outside his parents' door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, this is it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We again move along the hallway. We pass the Scottish wal of fame, Scottie from "Star Trek", Sir Walter Scott, Sir  Harry Lauder, Sheena Easton, Al Pacino, Billy Connolly, t the CAMERA BACKTRACKS to Pacino, where it HOLDS MOMENTARI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, Dad, we're here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May comes up, wearing a fancy country and western outfit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Charlie is this the wee Harriet.  Ah, she's beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's so sweet. I hope you keep her. (calling) Stuart, come out here. You tube.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he comes up, Stuart is wearing only a shirt with his boxer shorts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, it's the wee Harriet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuart, put your pants on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold your horses. (calling to William) Heed! Pants!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William comes around the corner with his pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, what's Al Pacino doing on the  Scottish wall of fame?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's for Tony. So, Charlie  tells me you're a butcher. Let's  talk meat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, no one wants to talk shop.  Especially butcher shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuart gets him in a half-Nelson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah! Dad, dad I have a back zit, man  it kills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie struggles to free himself. Stuart turns to greet  Harriet. As he reaches out his hand. Totally instinctively, Harriet grabs Stuart's hand and tw it behind his back. Charlie is startled, as his date has  just gotten Stuart into a Half-Nelson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (releasing his hand) I'm sorry. I just... You just  surprised me. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like this one Charlie. She's quite  a filly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm really embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be embarrassed about having a  good strong butcher's grip. Do you  link your own sausage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, ignore him. Come have a look at  some photos of Charlie when he was a  wee'n.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Mom, don't start with the pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Charlie, lighten up. You've got  a pickle up your ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering to Harriet) I'm gonna use the bathroom. You be  okay alone with them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kissing) Fine. Don't worry about it. Hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They smile as he leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make sure there's paper, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie picks up the pace, scared of what he might hear n

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make sure you leave the seat down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shutting her up) Ma, just show her the pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And light a match.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Harriet) He always leaves the seat up. He's  gotta learn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He closes the door, and shakes his head. What can he do?  Those are his parents. On the wall opposite the toilet is well-used dart board with pictures of the Queen Mother an Colonel Sanders. Hooked to the magazine caddie is a small container of darts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May excitedly shows Harriet family photo albums.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Charlie with his Uncle Ecky.  He's a policeman in Canada. And our  cousins Ruth and Jack. He's just got  a restraining order from his wife.  She's a lovely girl. This is Billy.  He's a member of parliament. He  drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a nice family you have.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE IN THE BATHROOM
dialogues.text: He doesn't seem in any hurry to leave either. He listens  through the door to Harriet enthusiastically looking thro old photos. Charlie glances down at a stack of National Enquirers on magazine rack. He flips through a few. He sees one of the absurd headlines: "ALIEN UFO SEX DIET" Charlie shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through door) Charlie was the cutest baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through door) You okay in there, Charlie? You didn't  fall in, did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through door) Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie then looks down at another article in the Enquire and reads:

dialogues.speaker: "WHO'S NEXT FOR MRS. X
dialogues.text: It is the article about Mrs. X -- the axe-murderer who ki her husbands on their honeymoons and then marries again u a different identity.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: May is quickly flipping through a photo album, pointing o pictures of relatives as she goes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe the resemblance  between you and Charlie, Mrs.  MacKenzie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Harriet speaking in the b.g., Charlie continues read now absorbed in the article about the 3 victims:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through door) You have the same smile. It's so  incredible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting in the front seat of Charlie's car, smiling, cont a great meal, a great night out with Charlie and a nice  evening with his parents. Slowly PAN across the front seat to Charlie. A nervous an "what the hell am I getting myself into" look on his face

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, that was some move you put on my  Dad, there. Did you study Karate,  or...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Not officially. I dated a guy  for a while who ran a studio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, the martial arts expert. The  north-south guy. Here in San  Francisco?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, Miami.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks straight ahead, trying to act unfazed. But, he's very phased -- his expression is covered in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was that before Atlantic City, or  after?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that was years ago. Atlantic  City was recent. I didn't care for  Atlantic City. A town full of gamblers  and lounge singers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He keeps driving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie walks through the precinct towards Tony's office, holding the National Enquirer in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Charlie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Tony back there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sergeant nods and Charlie heads back to the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.K., Tony. Do you have the K673  form completed yet, that street vendor  incident on Powell Street?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (really bummed) Yes, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony, do you mind my saying that you  seem a little down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain. It's about my work. About  being a policeman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony, if there's anything wrong, I'm  here to listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. And that's what's irritating,  you're too nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too nice!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, You're my captain for gods sakes.  You should be constantly on my case,  like the captain on Starsky and Hutch.  Once a week you should routinely  haul my ass into your office, accuse  me of being a maverick and complain  to me that you're sick and tired of  defending my screwball antics to the  commissioner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, as you may know, Tony. I don't  report to a commissioner. I report  to a committee, some of whom are  appointed, some elected and the  remainder co-opted on a bi-annual  basis. A quorum --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Police work should be all about  running around, following up crazy  hunches that turn out to be right,  going out on a limb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well Tony, I've never seen it that  way. For me police work is all about  following procedure and remaining  accountable to the general public.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Captain! When I joined the police  force, I thought I was going to be  Serpico and unfortunately I ended up  being Toma. I would have settled for  Beretta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's interesting Tony. I'm perturbed  that you should be so disillusioned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Tony, I gotta talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hello, Charlie. Look, I'm in the  way here. You guys probably have  something you want to talk about,  and Tony, if you've still got stuff  you want to sort out, please, you  know where the suggestion box is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Captain exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice guy. Hey, what's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm having doubts about being a cop  again. It's not like how it is on  cop shows. All I do is fill out papers  and reports.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me get this straight, your Captain  hasn't threatened to have you up on  charges so fast you won't know what  hit you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! He's never once said to me that  he was going to "throw the book at  me so hard it'll knock my ass from  here till Tuesday." Anyways what's  up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie pulls out the National Enquirer (the one on MRS. the Honeymoon Killer).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you heard of this case? Mrs. X?  She murders her husbands on their  honeymoons and then changes her  identity and marries again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never heard of it. So what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curious, that's all. I read about  it, and... (after a pause) I think I'm dating Mrs. X.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause) Two words, Charlie. Get therapy.  They have doctors that deal  specifically with this illness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's adding up, Tony. One of  the victims was a martial arts expert.  Last night at dinner, she put a  martial arts move on my dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There about twenty thousand people  in San Francisco who are martial  arts experts. Should I arrest all of  them too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they also say Ralph in their sleep  I think it'd be a good start. (showing him paper) Ralph Elliot. A plumber from San  Francisco. Missing since his  honeymoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're just getting scared. Like the  dream, you feel Harriet could be the  one, so you start to suspect her of  things, 'cause deep down you're scared  that if she is the one, you'll marry,  and marriage to you is death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, don't analyze my dreams, okay?  They're my dreams. Analyze your own  dreams. (a beat) It's not a marrying thing, Tony.  It's a murdering thing. (showing him paper) Harriet lived in Atlantic City, right?  Well so did this guy, right around  the same time she left town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading article) "Larry Leonard, a crooner who made a  name for himself for being able to  sing in six different languages the  song "Only You". (putting paper down) Does she know the song "Only You?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. It hasn't come up yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie, move past it. You're running  your life by the National Enquirer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensively) What? It's the fifth highest  circulating newspaper in the United  States. (taking paper back) Mrs. X. Please. Look it up.

dialogues.speaker: COMPUTER ROOM AT POLICE STATION
dialogues.text: Charlie and Tony are in the back with KATHY, a stocky bla woman in uniform, who works in the files department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no record of any deaths. All  three of these guys were reported  missing around the time of their  honeymoon, but so were the wives. No  pictures of any of the brides. For  all we know they just picked up and  moved away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Ralph Elliot, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie, you're talking about three  guys over a seven year span. That's  hardly news. No deaths. Elopement in  this state, as of this day, is still  not illegal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: the article) Yeah well murder is. And this article  says that these men were murdered by  the same woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. MacKenzie, we've found that,  most National Enquirer articles are  actually based on our own police  reports. They take the facts and  fabricate a story around them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true, Charlie. You gotta realize  that. I mean, personally, I would  lie to you, but Kathy... has this  crazy notion of always telling the  truth. (patting his back) You feel better now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It guess so. It's just... if I had a  photo of Harriet, I could show it to  the relatives or friends of Mrs. X's  victims to identify her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie, listen to me! There is no  Mrs. X! Drop it! Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie knocks on the door. Rose answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thrilled) You're back. But Harriet's not here  yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I could wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. That would be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She then starts to slowly close the door. He props it ope with his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside? I was hoping...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (letting him in) I'm glad you asked. I didn't want to  be so forward. I mean, if you're  waiting inside, then you feel  obligated to entertain me and keep  up the conversation just to be polite,  and really your head might be totally  elsewhere and then there's the chance  that you would really want to talk  and it's me who'd be busy, but in an  attempt not to be rude, I sit there  and listen to some story that you  don't really want to tell and I don't  really have time to hear. You know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't agree with you more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think about a lot of things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, if you have work to do, you go  right ahead. ("ah, here's an angle") I mean, to tell you the truth, I'd  love to see your work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay! What would you like me to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't want to see you work. I  was talking about your work. Your  photographs. That one that I saw was  so, wonderful, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet's far more talented than I  am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sure it's so subjective  anyway and... (out of patience) Rose, show me your photos.

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHS
dialogues.text: There are two kinds. Beautiful travel pictures and very e black and white portraits of young men and women. All wit slight sadomasochistic quality. At the bottom of every ph is says: "Seasons Greetings".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, these are some interesting photos  here. Very impressive. Nice shots of  Sauselito and... some good bondage  shots. A lot of people wouldn't think  to mix the two subjects, but they're  really a natural together. (new thought) Hey, you wouldn't happen to have any  pictures of Harriet by chance, would  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: her cards) Well, I don't think she'd wanna do  this sort of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, not that. Just, in general  some photos. Any little snapshot  would do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt I'd have any. Harriet hates  being photographed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of a key in the door as Harriet enters the  apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose -- did I see Charlie's car out  in front?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in here, Harriet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking in) What are you guys doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (covering up) Oh, nothing. Just looking through  some of Rose's work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Charlie wanted a photo of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that. That too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why of me, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sentimental reasons. Something  to remind me of you when we're not  together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes him in her arms and gives him a knee buckling k

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, can you remember that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, it's just, I was gonna give  one to my parents, too, and... (getting nowhere) Another time would be fine. It's  hardly a matter of life and death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the news tonight, regarding a  Beverly Hills Jeweler, Morris Cohan,  who died last week, police are now  suspecting that Morris's partner,  Lawrence Sachs, may have murdered  him with an untraceable poison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reveal: we are in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie is on a Stair Master, as Harriet walks in wearing robe. The TV is on in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Downstairs. I have a surprise for  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. I just wanna do a quick twenty  minutes on the Stair Master before  bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet drops her robe, and from over her shoulder we see that Charlie prefers what he sees to working out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do forty tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting into bed) I got something much healthier for  you than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls out a milkshake from behind her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a health shake. Eggs, malt,  cinnamon, oranges. It's great. I  mixed it up downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: THE TV SET
dialogues.text: continues on about poisons and poisoners. Charlie glances it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poisoning has become the second  leading method of murder in recent  years, due to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie watches the TV, looking a bit disturbed. Harriet  offers him the shake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, look, I'm full. Dinner and...  No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll like it Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, really, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting it up to his  lips) You won't try it. I spent twenty  minutes making it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes it. Lifts it to his mouth... then puts it on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sniffing it) Ummm. Smells good. Maybe I'll take  some to the office tomorrow. (running into bathroom) I'm gonna brush my teeth. Be right  back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie goes into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE'S BATHROOM
dialogues.text: Harriet comes into the bathroom and lays the empty glass  down on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna take a quick shower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie notices the empty glass on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet, where did the shake go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you care? I drank it. (getting into shower) You could have at least tried it.  You make me feel bad sometimes,  Charlie. I don't know why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With her in the shower, he sneaks back into the bedroom a checks the trash can. Nothing. Then he runs around the be to the other trash can. Nothing. He looks thoroughly confused as she enter the bedroom, we a towel. She takes the towel off as she slips underneath covers. He gets into bed next to her. She gives him a kis

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. I'm a little sensitive. You  didn't want to drink my milkshake.  So what -- right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Regarding the murder between the two  partners, we talked to Toxicologist  Dr. Show on the issue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie and Harriet are watching the news show. DOCTOR SH is patched in via the Anchorman's close circuit TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor, is it possible that one could  be poisoned with no trace at all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly. There are plants that  grow very commonly in our own backyard  that could easily be fermented into  poison. Take for instance the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting nervous;  blocking out TV) Harriet, why don't we shut the light  off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? And how easy it that to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scarily enough, quite simple. You  merely take the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blocking out the TV  again) Maybe we should turn the light back  on. Yeah that's better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie, what's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's just... (re: the TV) The TV. You can't even watch the  news these days without getting  depressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, Charlie. And it's not just  that. Look at the things people are  doing. Partners killing each other...  I mean, you hear a story like that,  and... who can you really trust these  days?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like, have you ever stood with  someone at the edge of a cliff, or  the edge of a subway platform, and  you think, just for a split second,  "What if I pushed him?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't really take the subway  ever, so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie turns over on his side, she cuddles up behind him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just making a point of how many  times we trust people with our lives.  I mean, look at us. If you didn't  trust me, you would never be able to  fall asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at you, you're sleeping. Look  how vulnerable you are. I mean, I  could do anything at that point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervous) What could you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sweet and innocent) Anything. You're lying on your side,  asleep, I could... stick a needle in  your ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grabbing his ear at  the thought) Aahhh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just making a point of what a  good relationship we have. Goodnight,  sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks very uneasy. She kisses him and shuts off the li The moon gives the room an eerie glow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't close her eyes. He's scared to close his. Pau

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both look over at each other. She closes her eyes. H takes a deep breath and then closes his eyes. And covers his ear with his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie is on the crowded platform. Next to him is an old lady with a lot of shopping bags. Three kids on skateboar whiz by and accidentally knock bags out of her hands. Cat toys and cans of cat food go everywhere. Charlie bends do and starts to help her gather her stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you very much, young man. I've  gotta get all this stuff back to my  children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your children?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I say my children I mean my  cats. You see my children moved out  years ago, so all I've got is my  cats. I have over one hundred of  them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a lot of cats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie looks up and sees Harriet waving to him from the  subway stairs. He waves back and motions. "I'll be there a second", and continues to help the old lady. She watche from the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see this red toy? That's for the  Captain, he's finicky. and this blue  one? That's for Marco Polo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two train headlights are seen off in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a name for all of your  cats?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie glances over at Harriet, who slowly makes her way down the platform towards him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see! There's Winston Churchill,  Reda Sovine, Thomas Edison, Andrew  Carnegie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train is getting closer and closer, and so is Harriet

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...He was Scottish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet moves forward a step, Charlie moves back a step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasn't he Irish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Harriet seems to get closer Charlie continues to back picking up cat toys. Charlie realizes he has no where els to turn. so he side steps down the platform, never stoppi his conversation with the lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually he was Scottish. Trust me,  I know these things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet is moving in on him. Charlie steadily makes his w down the platform, feigning accidentally kicking cat food down the platform. The old lady is unsure what is going o she tries to keep up with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that you say it, he was Scotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie runs out of platform. Harriet is very close to hi The train is closer, so is Harriet. Charlie lets out a sc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noooooo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
