dialogues.text: Charlie is standing at the edge of the platform, Harriet a good six or seven feet away as the train passes by. Cha is safe. People are all staring at Charlie curiously,  including Harriet and the old lady. Charlie is embarrasse

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (embarrassed) Nooooooo, Scotch is a drink. Scots  are a people. Sorry, that just always  bugged me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one knows what is going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I didn't know it meant so  much to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Harriet.

dialogues.speaker: DEATHS, AND MARRIAGES.
dialogues.text: We find Charlie at the marriage counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Sir, can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to put in an announcement  of my parents forty-fifth wedding  anniversary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, it's $4.50 per word, and you've  got a choice of standard or bold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bold, and here, I've written it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie looks over to the deaths counter. He overhears tw obituary assistants having a conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Frank, busy week?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've only got two. It's dead around  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both assistants laugh. Charlie is mildly bemused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I've got this one guy, a  tourist. He had a heart attack on a  cable car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like he left his heart in San  Francisco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, that's a real person you're  talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right, I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there's this other guy Elliot,  Ralph. Plumber, disappeared four  months ago. Body found in a sewer. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (despite himself) I guess he took his work too  seriously, and his life went down  the drain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did they mention anything about his  wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crest fallen) You're right, I feel bad. Point taken.  I'm mean, these are real people we're  talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm serious. Did he mention the  wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You made your point. I was wrong to  make a joke about a person's life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really want to know about his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crying and shouting) O.K., you win. I'm a bad, bad person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank take it easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he's right! (pounding his head  with his fists) I'm for shit, I'm one insensitive  asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there any mention of the wife? At  all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NO! THERE'S NO MENTION OF THE WIFE!  YOU HAPPY!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie stands outside the announcement office, terrified

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet is talking to a CUSTOMER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. (beat) I think you're a terrific woman. (beat) I just don't think we should see  each other anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She moves around to Charlie. She lifts his chin so that h is looking directly into her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? And tell me the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truth. Okay. The truth is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is so close to him, and so very beautiful, it's  distracting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truth is... I'm afraid that you  are... (he can't) You're going to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... the truth is that I'm afraid  you're going to ki... leave me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to "cleave you?" What does  that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave me. Not "cleave me." Reject  me. And so I decided to take matters  into my own hands and get it over  with by...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rejecting me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he feels awful) Purely preventive... It's not anything  you've done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that... So why are you leaving  me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heartbroken) Harriet, maybe I'm not meant to be  in a relationship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A single tear runs down her cheek. She brushes it away  quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never wanted to hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't. At least you left early  on. (she's crying) So, that's it, then. I've got a lot  of work to do. (to Customer) Now, where were we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie lies on the bar head down. Tony rushes in, looks  around and sees Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without lifting head) Two hours and four minutes. Tony, I  need you, and two hours and four  minutes later you show up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. I know it was irresponsible  to stay at the drug bust until it  was over, but... What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly sitting up) I'm gonna tell you, but when I do,  just say nothing. Don't judge me.  Just be my friend. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I broke up with Harriet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your point?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I just... why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony, she's a killer. The...  everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But nothing's proven. The only thing  you're actually sure she did so far  is she's treated you like a King.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno, Tony, I just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides, everyone has something going  on with them. I mean, you can't find  everything in one person. I mean,  she's bright, she's funny, she's  independent. So maybe, and it's really  just a maybe, she kills her husbands.  Marriage is give and take, Man. You  take the good with the bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie lies in bed. He's writing in his journal. He star out into space. Inspired, he writes...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: pauses a moment to reflect, then writes...

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Thinks of something else and writes...

dialogues.speaker: THIS POEM SUCKS
dialogues.text: His hand reaches across and scratches it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie is exiting a vintage record store. Suddenly he fi himself face to face with Sherri. She's accompanied by a  handsome young man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. How're you doing. (he glances at her  friend) Good, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm okay. This is Michael. Michael,  this is Charlie MacKenzie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Why don't you two talk. I'm  going over there to buy some  magazines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks over to a magazine stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That good looking and he can read!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm teaching him. I heard you have a  new girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We broke up. There were problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Problems?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Difficulties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me guess... (smiles) She's a murderer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a moment, Charlie is too stunned to respond. Then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you just say that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) What else is left?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's on the Stair Master, stepping very lethargically. Th TELEPHONE RINGS: He goes to answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through phone) Not that it matters anymore, but I  thought you should know -- someone  just turned themselves in for the  murder of Ralph Elliot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Did she confess to the other  murders?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just the plumber so far, but she'll  come along. (after a pause) A little old lady from Pacific  Heights. Said he overcharged her on  a leaking sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really. Leaky sink, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, crime to stop. Gotta go.  I'll catch you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony hangs up. Charlie stops pedaling on the bike. Now he really feels like shit. Harriet's not a killer. Sherri's a cheater. He races out of the bedroom. Moments later he appears, puts on a pair of pants over hi exercise shorts, then races out the door again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie races along towards Harriet's house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He races up to the door and starts to bang and knock and  ring...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through door) Harriet, it's me, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go away, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've gotta talk to you, cause I miss  you, and I made a mistake... and if  you give me another chance I'll  change. I will. I promise. I'll get  help, or therapy, or... Yeah, that'll  be great. Therapy. Even twice a week.  I'll check with my insurance to see  if I'm covered, but forget that.  Harriet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chain opens on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really hurt me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll make it up to you, can we at  least talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose steps up behind Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AAAhhhhhh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she now proceeds  to be let in by  Harriet) Trust your first instincts, Charlie.  You never do. It's your big mistake.  That and the haircut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once again, baffled by Rose, Charlie touches his hair, sh it off and looks Harriet right in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to lose you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't lose me. You rejected me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm unrejecting you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do I know you won't reject me  again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a long pause) I love you. But you blew it, Charlie,  you blew it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes into the house. Charlie stands there dejected. H knows he's blown it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet is doing a load of laundry consisting of bloodied work clothes. Suddenly she can hear the sound of MUSIC, v loudly. Annoyed, she goes out her front door to tell her neighbor off. Just as she's about to knock on the door, she realiz it's not the source of the music. At that moment her neig who is a STEWARDESS, comes out in nightclothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mean to be a pain, but I'm a  stewardess, and I have an early flight  out in the morning. Can you please  keep your music down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it was coming from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But someone keeps shouting your name  over and over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puzzled, Harriet rushes back to her own balcony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet rushes out and smiles as she sees the source of t noise. Charlie serenades Harriet in the street below,  accompanied by a TRUMPETER with a MUTE, a DOUBLE BASS PLA AND A GUY ON A SNARE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARRIET, HARRIET HARD-HEARTED  HARBINGER OF HAGGIS  BEAUTIFUL, BEMUSED BELLICOSE BUTCHER UNTRUST-ING UNKNOW-ING UNLOV-ING HE WANTS YOU BACK HE SCREAMS INTO  THE NIGHT AIR LIKE A FIREMAN GOING  TO A WINDOW THAT HAS NO FIRE EXCEPT  THE PASSION OF HIS HEART  I AM LONELY, IT'S REALLY HARD THIS POEM SUCKS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crowd has gathered in the street and spectators group o their balconies. They break out into APPLAUSE. Charlie pr takes the applause and bows to Harriet. She throws him a  flower. He's won her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Romantic with candles surrounding the tub. Harriet and Ch are bathing together. Wherever one of them moves, the wat extinguishes a candle and Charlie lights it. This is keep him pretty busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been there for almost a year. I  only planned on stay with her for a  few weeks, but she gets upset every  time I say I'm moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were close as kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I pretty much raised her. You know  the scene. Depressed mother...  withdrawn father. (she remembers) My dad was a photographer too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hated it. Trudging off to those  weddings every Saturday night. Other  people's celebrations he called it.  He said sometimes they didn't even  offer him a glass of soda. He had a  small studio, and every year at  Christmas he'd take a picture of me  and Rose and put it in the window on  a little card that said "Seasons  Greetings." Awful pictures. It's  like... I could see his pain in my  face. Anyway, me and my sister worked  with our "childhood issues" in  different ways. She became a  photographer and I became phobic  about having my picture taken. It's  quite a family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are they now? Your parents?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead. Car accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a RING at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet, its for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie comes out of the bathroom in a robe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie, I want you to meet a friend  of mine. Say hi to Ralph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shocked) Ralph?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A plain looking lady in her thirties, RALPH, is sitting b the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delighted) Oh, like Ralph, the lady carpenter  in Green Acres!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ecstatic) Nice? It's more than nice. It's great  to meet you. It's fantastic to meet  you. I just, I can't tell you how  glad I am. Ralph. Really. I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, thank you, I've heard a lot of  nice things about you too, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rushes over to hug her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Ralphie, I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swept up in his enthusiasm his towel falls off. Harriet i shocked, but amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll leave you guys alone. Have a  great time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie realizes he is naked. His arms are still wrapped  around Ralph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm naked, aren't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, yes, you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should really get dressed now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hurriedly puts his towel back on, bolts to the bedroom door. Just before he enters, he pauses and turns to Ralph

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ralph) Call me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Harriet; a little  confused) Friendly guy.

dialogues.speaker: A KITCHEN DOOR OPENS...
dialogues.text: and Charlie's mother, MAY, shoulders her way through the  door, carrying a HAPPY ANNIVERSARY CAKE with a big 45 wri on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May and Stuart's 45 year anniversary party. UNCLE ANGUS i at the piano playing "Happy Anniversary" as Charlie's par all their friends and Harriet all sit around the piano

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy Anniversary to you... (Etc.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The song ends. May and Stuart blow out the candles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, everyone come and get a piece  of cake and some milk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Dad, I got an anniversary present  for you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuart looks up, and Charlie gets him in a headlock and p him to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm proud of you, son. I'm proud of  you. (Stuart addresses the  group) I just wanna propose a toast. To my  wife. Forty five years ago today May  and I got married. Some of you were  there, some of you weren't born yet,  some of you are now dead, but... We  both said, "I do" and we haven't  agreed on a single thing since. But,  I'm glad I married you May cause...  It could have been worse and  besides... I still love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kiss and everyone APPLAUDS. Uncle Angus breaks into, "Stand By Your Man." May and Stuart start to dance. Charl looks at another young couple who are touched by this sin display of love. He looks over at Harriet. Stuart and May feed each other cake. Charlie approaches Harriet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet, I wanna talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, you really made some impression  with Ralph. She can't get over you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stalling; nervous) I'm just so happy for you to have  friends like Ralph. What a great  friend to have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is everything all right, Charlie?  You're perspiring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet... marry me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to have a wedding. With you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Charlie. It's so good  like it is. Why don't we just live  together first?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because, I love you and I want you  to marry me and be with me for 45  years. I want you to have my children,  and I want to have your children. I  know that sounds like a lot of  children, and they might not all get  along, but... I'm finally ready to  trust you and to make a commitment.  Marry me, Harriet, please. Be my  wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet flinches slightly at the word "Wife", but Charlie too wrapped up in the moment to notice. Stuart addresses group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to thank Charlie for throwing  us this party. I hope some day you  have the same great 45 years that  we've had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People clap and smile. Harriet looks at Charlie. He has t in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At first it doesn't register. Then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get married, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from across room) Harriet, come here a minute. I want  you and Uncle Angus to play a song  together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet and Charlie kiss one last time and she goes to th piano. Charlie stays in the corner, and Tony comes over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, sorry I'm so late. What's  happening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. Nothing at all. Just two  little things... (as Tony looks in) That woman over there in the corner...  She's Harriet's friend, and her name  is Ralph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And secondly... That woman over  there... (Re: Harriet) That's Harriet, and we're getting  married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited) Fantastic... What did I tell you.  She's a great girl. And the last  thing in the world she'd be is a  murderer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then Harriet begins singing at the piano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) ONLY YOU... CAN MAKE THIS WORLD SEEM RIGHT... ONLY YOU... CAN MAKE THIS DARKNESS LIGHT..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony and Charlie look at each other. "Only you?" Then Cha looks at his bride with confidence. He walks over and joins her. She sings to him. It's a mom

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie and Harriet pick out a diamond ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie and Harriet point to brochures of the different c they could go to on their honeymoon. They decide on a pic of the "DRY CREEK LODGE" in Oregon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are getting their blood tests back. Harriet looks at hers, casually. Charlie is nervous. Reluctantly he opens file and looks at it. He is pleased with the results and  does a victory dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie and Harriet are being married. Harriet is in a  beautiful wedding gown. Charlie is wearing a kilt. Tony i the best man. He also wears a kilt. Stuart, also kilted,  May, the whole family along with a hundred well-wishers a in attendance. The SCOTTISH MINISTER presides. Rose is in kilt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Mr. MacKenzie, if you will take  this woman to be your wife, through  thick and thin, for better or for  worse, please say: "I do"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Harriet, if you will take this  man, through good times and bad, for  ever and ever, as your husband, please  say "I Do"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet starts to speak; but right before the words come  out, she stares into Charlie's eyes and STOPS. Charlie lo nervous. So does the Scottish Minister. So does Tony. So  does everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a long pause;  finally:) I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Charlie... Kiss the beautiful  bride!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie and Harriet kiss. We can see (though Charlie can' Harriet has a strange unsure expression on her face. Tony notices it though and can't figure it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get pissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wedding march kicks in being played by a drunken Scot on BAGPIPES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Scottish accordionist and a Drummer play SCOTLAND THE B Some OLDER SCOTTISH AUNTIES are CLAPPING and HOOTING LOUD along with the tune. Some young girl COUSINS in tradition Scottish costume, dance the sword dance along to SCOTLAND THE BRAVE. We pass the buffet which we see is catered by "Meats Of T World." Then we pass a very drunken Stuart in a heated  discussion with four other people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Golden Gate park was designed  by a Scotsman, MacClaren, which is  who MacClaren park was named after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others agree heartily. May and Tony are dancing. May is dancing uncomfortably cl She keeps sliding her hand down to his ass, which he then has to move back to his shoulder. Then we come to William, who's reluctantly at the childre table. All his little cousins are queuing up for a chance feel his head. We find Charlie in a corner. One of the hooting Scottish  aunties is trying to get him to have another Scotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (proffering the Scotch) Charlie, get this down your neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Auntie Molly if I have another one  I'll end up underneath the table  with my kilt over my head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony joins them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Harriet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Oh, there she is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's in the corner by herself looking weird and ominous. She has enough food in front or her for three people. She eats ravenously and incessantly. Charlie goes over to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little hungry, were you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At that moment, a FLASH goes off. Harriet looks up angril

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then she realizes it's Rose. She calms down and smiles.  Charlie looks at her, a little peculiarly, but Harriet re her composure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. The flash just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band kicks into a new dance. A YOUNG BOY comes up to bagpipe man with a shot of whiskey and whispers into his  ear. The bagpipe man stops the song, downs the whiskey an then breaks into Rod Stewart's "IF YOU THINK I'M SEXY." F across the room we hear Stuart singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (full volume; singing) IF YOU THINK I'M SEXY... AND YOU WANT MY BODY... COME ON BABY LET ME KNOW.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stuart gives the Bagpiper the thumbs up. The young people the room start to jam, and then one by one the other gues start getting into the swing of things. The bagpipe man  continues playing. It is clear that he is far too drunk t play. He slowly keels over, drunk. And as he falls over f first, he lands on his Bagpipes. The bagpipes let out an  ATONAL DEFLATING SOUND like the last dying throes of a  tortured animal. The BAGPIPE WAIL extends into the next s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait 'til you see this place, Harriet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drive along the beautiful coast. Harriet is still ea They're listening to TEENAGE FAN CLUB.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Teenage Fan Club. They're  from Scotland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll have the whole lodge to  ourselves practically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't wait, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you could be me, so you could  know how great it feels to be with  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sounds wonderful

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think that would be a good  line for a poem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honestly? It sounds a little Hallmark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's a little Seals and Croft.  I have a habit of sabotaging  relationships, and there were a  million times during me and you that  I could have blown this, and I just  thank God that I didn't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony is at his desk. The captain kicks open the door, kno Tony's feet off the desk. The captain is now dressed in  suspenders, a loosened tie, and a shirt with pit stains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.K., Spiletti, I got word from  upstairs that you been pokin' your  nose into that Ralph Elliot case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't "yes, Captain" me, Spiletti.  You're outta line. This is strictly  homicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain, I got this friend...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friend? Yeah, we all got friends,  Spiletti. I'm warning you, Stay away  from this one. Back off, Italian  boy. You're getting too close to  this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain, I know what I'm doing. Trust  me. What's the news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe I'm doing this, but  that girl who confused to Ralph  Elliot's murder also confessed to  other murders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew she would! I knew it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, apparently she also confessed  to killing Abe Lincoln, Julius Caesar,  and Warren G. Harding. She's a nut,  Spiletti!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up) Oh, my god! I gotta go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, screw this one up Spiletti and  you'll be writing parking tickets  for the rest of your days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't let you down, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony exits for a beat, then pokes his head in the doorway

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's much better Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nice again) You think so? Well, thank you very  much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony hurries to his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop at a gas station with a small mini-mart. As Cha is filling the tank he notices Harriet slipping the key o of the ignition before she walks to the mini-mart for mor food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lamb chops, creamed spinach, stuffed  tomatoes and a Hershey Bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet arrives at the little Ma and Pa type mini-mart an smiles to Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they don't have all that, I'll  just take the Hershey bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony stands at the door, buzzing the buzzer to no respons

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are still driving along the coast. Charlie is eating his Hershey Bar. Harriet's eyes are becoming a bit glazed now, her movements a little static. She keeps looking beh them and out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you keep looking behind us  for? (joking) Is someone following you, or...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were. I think they're gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (curious; pausing) What do you mean, they were?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gas station guy. I thought he  was chasing us for a while, but I  guess he stopped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gas station guy? Why would the  gas station guy chase us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Charlie. I guess for  not paying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean not paying? You  didn't pay him for the gas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I forgot to pay... I didn't want to  be away from you for any longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you just left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. And you're an accomplice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops mid-bite on his Hershey Bar. He's confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Charlie, don't you get it?  We're a team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going with it) I can play that game. I'll get the  next gas station. Like Bonnie & Clyde.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He and Bonnie continue on the winding road and pass a sig that reads: "DRY CREEK LODGE - 40 MILES"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony knocks. No answer. He picks the lock and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose is tied up and lying in a pool of blood. Tony stops a beat, draws his gun and slowly walks over to her. Just he gets there, a SHUTTER CLICKS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (practically hysterical) What is it with the women in your  family?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just doing a murder series in  honor of the wedding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, this is real blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Harriet, give it to me. She's a  butcher. (Tony reacts) ...She owns a butcher shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a picture of Harriet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. No can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You took a picture at the party. I  saw it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It didn't come out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Rose. I need a photo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The picture didn't come out. (he waits) It was unflattering. In made her  look ten pounds heavier. (he waits) She's my sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's been implicated in a crime. I  need the photo to eliminate her as a  suspect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if she's not innocent. If she's,  you know, "quirky?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she's "quirky" we'll save Charlie's  life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose pulls out a photograph -- Charlie and Harriet. Looki young and in love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful old Colonial Mansion, nestled in the mountain and forests of the North-West. Romantic and from another  day. Charlie and Harriet pull up in front of it. The Valets open the door for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like a castle, Charlie. It's so  beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to the Dry Creek. You just  beat the rainstorm. Two hours later  and the roads'd probably be closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. If you could help us with the  luggage, we have these two in the  back seat and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they deal with the luggage, Harriet starts to walk awa from the hotel, away from the car, rain falling on her he She walks straight at the CAMERA, so only we can see her  expression. Her expression is one of simply "losing it".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet? What are you doing honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet turns around and smiles at Charlie. He smiles bac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie and Harriet stand at the desk. Harriet is not qui paying attention. Her attention span has slipped to none. She's fidgety. She looks around suspiciously at everythin and everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome, Sir. We have you with us  for four nights, Mr. MacKenzie. Dinner  reservations are at eight-thirty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. Sounds terrific.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also, you might wanna prepare some  candles by the bed. We're expecting  the rainstorm to get even worse. We  might even lose the power tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear that, Harriet? A storm.  I can't think of anything more  romantic than the two of us trapped  in our room in the middle of a rain  storm. (noticing her) You okay, Harriet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a little head-ache. (to clerk) Excuse me, is there a drug store in  the hotel? I want to get some aspirin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right beyond those trees, Ma'm.  Anything you need.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. Don't go anywhere. I'll be  right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet walks off to the lobby store, backwards, looking Charlie. Charlie watches her walk off. The Desk Clerk sit staring at Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think she's really got a head- ache?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, nothing. Here's your key. You're  in the Oak Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie looks back at the drug store, where Harriet is  shopping. She waves to him. Charlie looks back at the Des Clerk and grabs the key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FAX OF THE PHOTO OF CHARLIE & HARRIET coming out of a fax machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WALTER, the owner of the Plumbing store, dressed in overa takes the Fax out and then picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Ralph Elliot's wife, alright.  She had shorter hair in those days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MASTER CHO, the new owner of the studio, dressed in a gee looks at the same fax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Mrs. Richter gain much weight since  then, but it's definitely her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RANDY ROMANO, the owner, talks into the phone, holding up the faxed photo of Charlie and Harriet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's his little lollipop, alright.  Boy he loved her. I'll tell you, she  was a lot of fun. Smart. A doll face  to boot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony is on the phone. Kathy, seen before at the police  station, stands with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Circuits are out from the storm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony gets to the police station door and opens it. Kathy  follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Kathy) Keep trying the hotel. Tell the chief  I just chartered a plane up to Oregon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Police Captain enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points to his hair) See that Spiletti -- A gray hair!  Every day, Spiletti, I find another  one. And that's all due to you. Get  out there, and catch me some bad  guys!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not now, Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nice again) Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony dashes out of the police station and into his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful suite, with a fireplace burning a big stack o wood, with another stack next to it, with an AXE in it. M is playing softly on the stereo. And Charlie and Harriet  have just finished making love underneath the covers,  illuminated just by the light of the fireplace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the best honeymoon I could  ever imagine, Harriet. If we had to  pack and go home right now, I'd still  think it was the greatest honeymoon  ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet doesn't respond. Her head is turned from his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you agree, Harriet? Harriet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls the sheets away from her face to see that she is crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wiping her tears) What? What are you crying? What is  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nothing. It's just... I was  just thinking... We're married now.  And I always wanted to try and have  kids, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So do I. Look, there's nothing more  I'd like to do than have, kids, or...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just, I get scared that certain  things will happen, or...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? You're  gonna be a great Mom. I know you  will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not that, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me. Of course I'm not gonna  laugh. Kids is a big thing. It's  hard. I'm sure I have the same fears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we have kids, Charlie, things  happen. Kids are healthy and fine,  and some aren't, and I don't know if  I could live with myself if I gave  birth to a child with webbed feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie stops to think about this. Webbed feet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Webbed feet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think that's silly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. That's a natural fear. I've  thought about that fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It really worries me, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quite confused) Well, look, they have, doctors -- I  assume -- that deal, only with, webbed  feet. And, God Forbid, and I'm talking  strictly hypothetically, should that  happen, we'll find one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kissing him; happy  now) You're the greatest Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confused, to say the  least) Thanks. We should get ready for  dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small plane flies through the clouds. It's just Tony an DENNIS the pilot. Dennis never really realizes this is more than a sightsee tour, and constantly points out scenic points along the w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out your left side, you can see the  Sierra Nevada, which is the largest  mountain range west of the Rockies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. Rockies. I don't care. Oregon.  Move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie is dressed very sharply in sport coat and tie. He yells into the bathroom where we can see part of Harriet  from behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You almost ready? The first seating  is in five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from other room) I just wanna look good for you,  Charlie. That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you look great. I'm sure  you look...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet turns the corner, wearing a nice dress. Her hair  looks okay. She's wearing perfume. The only problem is, s has two lines of mascara running down her cheeks. She's b crying. Charlie looks curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I look okay, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie points to his own eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. You kind of look like Tammy  Faye Baker right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes back into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane descends towards the runway. The rain comes dow hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we prepare to land, we can see  off to our left Lake Shanony, which  is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just land. Don't worry about Lake  Shanony. I don't give a shit about  Lake Shanony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane touches down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain pours fantastically on the gothic castle. Wind blows hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A toast to our new friends, Charlie  and Harriet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful dining room with a small dance floor. Charlie sits at an intimate table for two with Harriet. A small b plays in the b.g., as the BAND LEADER is making the toast The five or six other couples in the restaurant also hold their glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...we're honored to be here for this  very special day in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CONCIERGE at this point interrupts to bring Charlie a TELEPHONE. Everyone stops and watches and waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to interrupt, Sir. There's  a phone call for you from town. (Charlie takes phone) They say it's quite urgent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The toast, as well as the entire room, stops -- almost li an E.F. Hutton commercial, waiting for Charlie's phone ca to finish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (curious) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony speaks into the phone frantically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie, you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. Couldn't be better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie, listen to me! It's her!  Harriet is Mrs. X! She killed Ralph  and the two other men!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie looks up across the table at Harriet who is compl caught up in the event of seeing how long she can keep he hand in the candle before it hurts. She puts it in, smiles then takes it out. She shakes her  hand, and repeats the process.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (talking softly) Look, that's great -- it just so  happens though, that I met... (louder than he had  hoped) Ralph, and much to my delight, not  only is she alive, but she's female.  I thought I told you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet looks at Charlie, very suspiciously. He looks bac at her, and tries to smile, pretending that he is having pleasant, and completely irrelevant conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose had a picture. It checked out.  It's her, Charlie. She is the  murderer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie, your food is getting cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie waves "One Minute" to Harriet, as she watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what do I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I called the police. All the roads  are closed, but they're on their  way. In the mean time just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The line goes DEAD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? (pressing receiver) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a matter, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to concierge) The phone just went dead. I was on  the phone and it went dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's quite common, sir. I'm sure  the lines'll be out in the whole  city 'til tomorrow. Enjoy your meal,  Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Concierge takes the phone away. Charlie turns slowly Harriet, genuinely scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened, Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing... Nothing happened. Just  the lines are down. Phone lines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, the band leader continues with his toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over microphone) ...so to these two young people, we  wish them a long and happy life  together and would like to play their  song. The Platters -- "Only You".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band starts to play "Only You". People APPLAUD. Harriet and Charlie just stare at each ot He knows. The older couple at the next table, MR. & MRS. LEVENS lean over to their table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about the traditional Bride &  Groom dance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another couple walks by and pulls them literally out of t their seats and onto the dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. It's a tradition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie finds himself in the middle of the dance floor da slowly with Harriet. He's scared out of his mind. The mus plays in the background. Harriet smiles strangely at him. tries to smile back, checking all the Exits, planning an  escape. Then suddenly, call it luckily, MR. LEVENSTEIN, interrupt

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Could I cut in on your  dance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. Sure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie gives her hand away to Mr. Levenstein. He takes M Levenstein's hand and starts to dance towards the EXIT, w suddenly the ELECTRICITY GOES OUT. The MUSIC is out. The  LIGHTS ARE OUT. In the dimmest of lights provided from the cloud covered  moon outside, Charlie runs across the dance floor, fighti for an exit to the outside. He arrives in someone's arms on his way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need your help! You have to help  me! I've married a...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The LIGHTS GO BACK ON and Charlie is in HARRIET'S ARMS ag Her face is near menacing now. She smiles a very disturbe grin. He doesn't know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (much too pleasant) Hello, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie and her are squared off. Neither speak. Suddenly  both of them are lifted into the air. They look down and the waiters and busboys picking them up onto chairs, thro them up in the air again and again. The MUSIC plays along loudly. Harriet watches Charlie very closely, as Charlie looks sc Then, the people start to carry them out of the room and  down the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's take 'em to their room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm sure they've had enough of  these crowds for one night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dinner. I didn't finish my dinner  yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smile, Charlie. Act like you're having  a good time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony is talking to an attractive young girl behind the ai Rent-A-Car booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Sir. The roads are all  closed. We can't rent any cars this  evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to rent me something. I've  gotta get up there. My friend's in  danger...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. CHARLIE & HARRIET'S ROOM - NIGHT The other hotel guests threw them inside. The room is all made up, the sheets are pulled down, the firewood is cut, the AXE is in the wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a good night, you two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on in. Stay for a nightcap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you two wanna be alone. See you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (demanding) Stay for a nightcap!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, I really don't think I should

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) STAY FOR A NIGHTCAP!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bellboy is frightened and runs away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting down the  hall after him) STAY FOR A NIGHTCAP!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet pulls Charlie back into the room, frightened that he's leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't go, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony runs out of the airport terminal where he sees a man his forties who's just entered his four wheel drive jeep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flashing his badge) Excuse me, Sir, I'm with the San  Francisco Police Department. I'm on  official business and I'm afraid I  have to commandeer your vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unfazed) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean no?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I happen to know for a fact that you  don't have the power to commandeer  my vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is true. (pause) Please can I commandeer your vehicle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To The Dry Creek Lodge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give you a lift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't want a lift, I really  want to commandeer the vehicle. Please  just let me commandeer the vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you just let me drive you  there? Really, I don't mind, it's on  my way. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to bend on the  commandeering thing are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if we get stopped will you at  least let me say that I commandeered  the vehicle, but I let you drive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm uncomfortable with that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie & Harriet are all alone. The voices trail off the hallway until they disappear. Charlie and Harriet sta at each other. Harriet blocks the door. Charlie looks aro the room. The Axe. The Corkscrew. The letter opener. The  fountain pen. At this point, everything in the room looks like a potential weapon. Harriet takes the axe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard you on the phone before,  Charlie. There's something I've got  to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frightened) Harriet, I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been married before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About my husbands?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. And I was meaning to have a  word with you. We could get an  annulment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screams) AAAhhhhhhh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the power goes off again. They're both in the da A scuffle. Charlie has restrained Harriet, throws her in walk-in closet and locks it. From behind the door, we hea Harriet WAILING. Which continues. Charlie picks up the axe, looks at it, relieved at his lu escape. He rushes to the door to escape. He opens it and  standing there is Rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaaaah, Rose, I never thought I'd be  so glad to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose smiles. Charlie puts down the axe. The lights flicke back on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going to the phone) Maybe the phones are working again  by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He listens for a dial tone. Beside the phone he sees a no He starts to read is:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Dear, Harriet. I just can't handle  the commitment. I'm leaving you.'  Signed, 'Charlie.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And behind him Rose approaches with the axe raised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is this? I didn't write  this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And at that moment he turns to find the AXE BEING FLUNG  THROUGH THE AIR AT his head. He ducks just in time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes another swing and she hits the lamp off the des and the room is in complete DARKNESS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie. Why did you marry Harriet?  I warned you not to marry her, didn't  I? I warned all of them. But none of  them listened to me. They all went  ahead and married her. She's the  pretty one. Where's Harriet? What  have you done with my sister, Harriet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing, Rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you've done something to my sister,  Harriet, I swear to God I'll kill  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We stay in Charlie's hip pocket as he tries to get away f what he can't see. He stays very silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the closet) Where are you, Charlie? What's going  on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Rose strikes a match. She lights a candle and comes  toward him. He looks around. The window is open. And Char is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony and the commandeered man drive through the swampy,  winding road on the way up to the hotel. Tony is drumming the dash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you stop doing that please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie tightropes along the ledge of the building. The s continues. Rose comes out on the ledge and starts to chas him. He rounds the bend. Charlie looks into one room and  sees MR. & MRS. LEVENSTEIN there. There's loud OPERA playing in the room

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call the police!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Levensteins prepare for bed. Charlie races by their  window. Then Rose races by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call the police!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Levenstein closes the curtains. He can't hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie races along the slippery ledge, almost falling at several points. Rose then appears on the roof holding the Axe, still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mostly to herself;  slurring most words) Charlie, did you like your note? I  thought it was pretty accurate. I  did all the husbands' notes. I can  forge anyone's handwriting, I can  write in anyone's style. See, I'm an  artist. Harriet isn't an artist.  Sure she could get a husband, but  she could never have done this. And  you know what I'm most proud of?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that, Rose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet never knew. She thought they  all just left her. I protected her.  She's my sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie turns and runs. Rose chases him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony breaks into the room with his gun drawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) Charlie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from closet) Tony, is that you? It's me, Harriet.  I'm in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carefully, Tony opens the closet door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony, Rose is trying to kill Charlie.  They're out on the ledge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not believing) Get on the floor and put your hands  behind your back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet willingly goes on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, anything. You've got to save  Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony slaps cuffs on her and takes her to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony is standing with his back to the window, between it Harriet. She looks out of the window and screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look! It's Charlie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Harriet's POV we see Charlie on the ledge edging alo He stops in horror when he sees Harriet, glances back to pursuing Rose, and rushes off. Tony looks behind him out the window. Nobody is there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear to you... It was Charlie...  Look! Now there's Rose!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose looks into the room, with the axe in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg you... Look! It is Rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, not again. (he glances at the  window) Aaaaah! Rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is opera music playing. Charlie rushes by, past the window. There is a beat and he comes back, staring inside amazement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Levenstein is in a Viking outfit. Mrs. Levenstein is full Norse Regalia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie gulps and rushes on, hastily pursued by Rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rose pulls the Axe back and swings, and the momentum of t swing pulls her feet out from under her, and on the slipp icy roof she falls and starts to slide. Just as she's about to go off the fifty foot high roof,  Charlie climbs down the roof. He stands over her. She's a to slip. Her hands are losing strength. Her fingers are  slipping. The rain is falling harder and harder. Charlie walks over to the cage where she's hanging on for life. He leans down to help her up, but just as he grabs on to hand, the drainpipe she's holding onto slips. She is now dangling from the roof, the rain falling harde and harder. Charlie now is nowhere near her. He then gets down on his knees on the roof and starts to climb down th side of the drainpipe to get her. Rose looks up helplessly at him. Not really asking for hi help. Not denying it. She's accepted her fate. Policemen, ambulances and spectators have gathered below bunches as Charlie climbs down the drainpipe, he himself  hanging on for dear life. He just reaches out far enough to grab her hand, and just he does, her drainpipe tears and falls into the crowd bel Charlie, then with all his strength -- his "where has thi strength been my whole life" strength -- pulls her up to roof next to him. Several policemen make their way onto the roof and come o to where Charlie is detaining Rose. The police take her,  handcuff her and cart her away. From the corner of the ro appears Tony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate to bother you on your  honeymoon, Charlie, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie looks beyond Tony and sees Harriet standing in th doorway. He goes over and puts his arm around Harriet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God. I'm sorry I doubted you,  but I thought you were the killer,  but you were acting pretty strange?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were going to leave  me, like the others. Thank God they  were just murdered. I thought they  were always leaving me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Below, Rose is put into a police car and taken off. The S disappear. So do the crowds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie is on stage looking very beatnik. He's reading hi poetry, but we can't hear it. He nods to someone off stag Harriet is in the audience, also looking very beatnik wit their three year old son, STUART, a miniature beatnik ver of Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dad was right. You don't lose  your muse once you're married. Nothing  changed, except I gained a great  son, Stuart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOUND UP on Charlie's poetry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARRIED MAN MOST MERRY AND IN CONCLUSION

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THIS POEM SUCKS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd goes crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOUSE MUSIC kicks on. It's Saturday Night by the Bay City Rollers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S-A-T-U-R-D-A-Y NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie comes off stage and joins his wife and child at t table. He is very happy.
